Award.AwardTitle: Elementary Preservice Teachers Mathematics Project Phase II: Developing Faculty Expertise

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Boston University Elementary Preservice Teachers Mathematics (EMP) Project Phase II builds on the outcomes of the NSF funded EMP project (CCLI #0837349, 2009-2011) and is extending the project to provide enhanced pedagogical support for faculty who are using the EMP materials with undergraduates. Five instructional units (30 lessons) for use in undergraduate mathematics content courses for elementary teachers were developed, tested and revised in Phase I. The present project has three goals: to investigate the feasibility of implementing and the resultant impact of three of the EMP instructional units (fractions, number theory and geometric measurement) in building pre-service teachers' knowledge of mathematics; to develop accompanying multimedia-based support materials for instructors focused on how to use discourse and arguments to build students' knowledge; and to investigate the promise of the multimedia support materials in terms of instructors' abilities to assist PSTs in understanding mathematics content for teaching.

Multi-media support materials for faculty (video clips, interactive presentations, web-based resources) that support a discourse/argumentation approach to teaching are being developed. The project is employing a research design that compares groups of faculty and PSTs (Preservice Teachers) at over 20 different institutions on the effects of the three modules with respect to building undergraduates' mathematical content knowledge for teaching. Different groups are accessing the instructor support materials that either do or do not include the multi-media resources. The project is using a research-based design and builds on prior work. It integrates the knowledge about the beliefs, attitudes, and mathematical backgrounds of preservice elementary teachers with an understanding of the needs of K-5 public education in mathematics. The project contributes to theory and research on the role of specialized content knowledge and discourse in preservice elementary content courses. Finally, it produces an innovative model and materials to support faculty in teaching mathematics courses for elementary education preservice teachers.

The project will contribute to the improvement of mathematics education by providing materials for teacher preparation programs and by supporting faculty members to help them implement the materials as designed. The research outcomes will contribute to the growing body of knowledge about the mathematical preparation of elementary school teachers. This project provides many faculty members responsible for preparing elementary teachers (e.g., mathematicians and teacher educators) with access to a wide array of innovative instructional materials and directions on how best to use them.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Elementary Preservice Teachers Mathematics (EMP) Project - Phase II was designed to improve the mathematical preparation of future elementary teachers through the development of course materials and instructor support tools. The project accomplished the following: 1) created and tested three EMP instructional units for use in mathematics content courses for undergraduates training to become elementary school teachers; 2) videotaped portions of EMP lessons for use by instructors; and 3) developed a web-based platform for disseminating these materials.

There has always been agreement among educators of the importance of mathematics content courses for future elementary school teachers. However, what mathematics should be studied (e.g., calculus, statistics) has undergone some dramatic shifts. Recent recommendations about what mathematics should be emphasized in these content courses include the importance of deepening preservice teachers’ understanding of elementary content and focusing on mathematical knowledge for teaching (Ball, Thames & Phelps, 2008; Greenberg & Walsh, 2008; U.S. Department of Education, 2008; Conference Board of the Mathematical Sciences, 2001, 2012). In addition, researchers have suggested that instruction in these courses should model methods that elementary teachers could use when teaching young children, such as group problem solving, active learning and discussions (Hodgson, 2001).

The three EMP units (Geometric Measurement, Fractions, and Number Theory) focused on foundational content following recommendations from the Common Core State Standards (National Governors Association Center for Best Practices, Council of Chief State School Officers, 2010) and The Mathematical Education of Teachers II (CBMS, 2012). Two design principles were used in the creation of all instructional materials: 1) problems focused upon content knowledge for teaching mathematics; and, 2) instruction focused on recurring cycles of collaborative problem solving and group discussion. The EMP units were specifically designed to situate the learning of the mathematics in a community where learning revolved around discussions and the construction of shared meaning, problem solving and the practices of teaching. Each unit contains six to ten lessons. For each lesson, there are student materials, instructor's guides, homework documents, assessments, answer keys, and PowerPoint presentations. Each instructor’s guide includes detailed information and suggestions for lesson implementation as well as common responses of preservice teachers. 

In order to further support instructors on how to use the EMP materials, lessons were filmed in undergraduate classes. One to five video clips were selected for each lesson. Each video clip shows an instructor enacting portions of a lesson with undergraduates, and includes written commentary to focus users on the use of research-based instructional practices to support learning. A web-based platform for instructors was created (www.elementarymathproject.com). All materials for each lesson as well as additional support documents including the video clips and documents on facilitating discussions, mathematical knowledge for teaching, and the key mathematical ideas were uploaded.

In order to examine the effectiveness of the EMP units. we used a repeated-measures quasi-experimental design focused on preservice teachers’ mathematical achievement. The specific research question we asked was: 

Did using the EMP materials to develop content knowledge for teaching mathematics (CKTM) affect preservice teachers’ overall scores on CKTM-focused assessments for the three units: Geometric Measurement, Fractions and Number Theory?

Field testing of all three units occurred over two academic years (September 2013 – May 2015) with 45 instructors at 33 four-year institutions across the U.S. and Canada (n = 1,494). Great care was taken to ensure a variety of institutions by size, selectivity, and geographic region was represented in the sample. The majority of the instructors that used the materials in their courses were full-time faculty (n = 33). The sample was equally representative of instructors whose main responsibility was either in an education department (n = 24) or a mathematics department (n = 20), with one instructor being jointly appointed. While we designed our materials for use in content courses for preservice elementary teachers, some of the field testing institutions used them in math methods courses (20% to 50% depending on the unit).

Following the use of each unit, statistically significant pre- to post-test increases occurred in preservice teachers’ mathematics achievement, with large effect sizes of 1.23 (Geometric Measurement), 1.51 (Fractions) and 1.71 (Number Theory). See Table 1. These results provide initial “proof of concept” support for the efficacy of the EMP units in raising mathematics achievement of future elementary school teachers. In addition, significant gains and large effect sizes were obtained regardless of course type or instructor affiliation. 

This project  adds to the body of work on the value of research-based instructional materials that are based on coherent design principles.  The EMP instructional units have great potential for improving the teaching of elementary mathematics. Across a range of institutions and with different instructors and students, the materials supported PSTs’ learning of mathematical knowledge for teaching.
